repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Todo

- [x] Good word wrapping
- [x] Parse lists:
  - Do we need a markdown parser?
     - ~https://github.com/jgm/lunamark: Comprehensive but large~
     - ~https://github.com/sebcat/lpeg-markdown: Too simple, doesn't handle nested lists.~
     - UPDATE: using the tree-sitter parser we bundle
- [ ] Also make it work for C files.
- [ ] Parse `@note`, `@defgroup`, `@brief`.
- [ ] Remove `gen_vimdoc.py` and `lua2dox.lua`
- [x] Generate docs for Luadoc classes
   - Done but commented out in this PR.

-    Adds a new predicate to be used in queries
+    @field [integer] TSMetadata @field [string] integer|string Adds a new
+    predicate to be used in queries

comment_data.body: Probably filter out classes beginning with `_`?

comment_data.body: Would it make sense to use this instead of our own LPEG grammar: https://github.com/tree-sitter-grammars/tree-sitter-luadoc
can we name it `gen_vimdoc.lua` (or `gen_help.lua`), for consistency
Sure as this develops, I'll rename this appropriately. Right now this is still driven through gen_vimdoc.py and is only used for Lua files.

comment_regular_data.body:
No worries but this is incredibly rough.

It's not obvious, but the code here basically allows us to generate full docs for functions too, so I might pivot this to try and remove the doxygen middleman and do classes later.

>  Do we need a markdown parser?

We have a tree-sitter markdown parser. Is LPEG preferred for some reason?

If this is done using treesitter, then we could later replace `gen_vimdoc.py` entirely, because we could feed the result of treesitter C parser into the tooling from this PR.

I'm really not sure treesitter is the right tool for this. Yes treesitter provides parsers, but it doesn't provide great APIs for what we're trying to achieve. The node structure, especially for C and Markdown, do not have a  an easy to follow hierarchy so there would need to be some normalisation step to put everything into a good shape.

Also note the Markdown parser doesn't have an active maintainer and is currently implemented as two separate parsers, so I'd be pretty nervous about depending on that.

I'm sure if enough time is put into it that we could make it work, but I feel it is reuse for the sake of reuse whilst making the stack a lot taller.

For C and Lua I don't think we really need a parser. Regexp should be good enough for parsing out prototypes. Otherwise a simple lpeg pattern can help us cover anything less trivial. It doesn't need to cover the whole language; just anything that follows a doc block. We also already depend on an lpeg grammar for the C API generators.

> If this is done using treesitter, then we could later replace gen_vimdoc.py entirely, because we could feed the result of treesitter C parser into the tooling from this PR.

I think we can replace gen_vimdoc.py by using most of the code here for C. We just need different patterns for the function prototypes.

> treesitter ... doesn't provide great APIs for what we're trying to achieve. The node structure, especially for C and Markdown, do not have a an easy to follow hierarchy ... Also note the Markdown parser doesn't have an active maintainer ...
>
> For C and Lua I don't think we really need a parser. Regexp should be good enough for parsing out prototypes. Otherwise a simple lpeg pattern can help us cover anything less trivial.

Interesting. Let's mention that in ~~luacats_parser.lua~~ `gen_vimdoc.lua` and the commit message, for future reference.

Ok, so I've spent quite a bit more time on this and gone through a few rabbit holes.

Creating a simple markdown parser using LPEG isn't reasonably possible AFAIK since you need to somehow keep track of indentation for identifying blocks.

Next I tried looking at some other Markdown parsers implemented manually.
- First looked at https://github.com/mpeterv/markdown and it's _ok_, but wasn't particularly happy with its design.
- Then found https://github.com/frostming/marko, which is implemented in Python (very good Python I might add). So I tried to see if I could remove everything we didn't need and port to Lua. Turns out with just the block level stuff (list, paragraphs and code blocks) you're still left with 500-800 LOC. And that's with a good design.

**TLDR**

So I finally gave in and attempted to use the tree-sitter parser we bundle. I've got it to work pretty well, but it certainly has some challenges. One example being codeblocks seems to be parsed with incorrect ranges when in nested blocks like lists. It also doesn't correctly parse some stuff because of indentation in places.

I've been able to generate `diagnostic.txt` 95% the same to how it was with `gen_vimdoc.py` which I'm pretty happy with so this seems like a good route.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(docs): replace lua2dox.lua
